Author: Junko Yoshida
Keywords: Asic, Automotive, Business Topics, Cloud Computing, Computers And Peripherals, Consumer Electronics & Appliances, Digital, Home Automation, Industries, Mergers & Acquisitions, Microcontroller, Microprocessor, Mission Critical, Mobile, PCs, Servers, SoC, Transportation
Article: MADISON, Wis. â EE Times has learned that Wave Computing (Campbell, California), a startup focused on the development of AI systems using its massively parallel dataflow architecture, will announce later this week that it has acquired MIPS Technologies, a storied but beleaguered Silicon Valley company that developed MIPS processor architecture and related processing cores. The move will allow Wave Computing to expand from AI training in data centers to AI inference for embedded systems. EE Times called Wave Computing's CEO Derek Meyer, and asked him what has motivated the startup to make such a move. He told EE Times, âOur strategy has always been to push our dataflow fabric out to the edge.â The acquisition should give Wave Computing an opportunity to infuse its scalable dataflow technology with MIPSâs RISC processors while plugging it into MIPSâs ecosystem. Bold move  An AI startup with just 100 employees acquiring another company of equal size â with long history and deep roots in the tech community â is a rare coup. Several industry analysts called Waveâs move âboldâ and noted that the decision could help elevate the buyer in the AI market. âI think it is bold for a small startup to think this big, to reach for market extension before their first product is out,” said Karl Freund, lead analyst for HPC and Deep Learning at Moor Insights & Strategy. “Risky, perhaps, but thatâs what it takes.â MIPS isnât just any old company, though. Despite its diminsihed position in the processor core IP market, MIPS architecture still has numerous supporters and nostalgic believers. More importantly, a broad range of customers is sticking with MIPS â including Microchip, Mobileye (now an Intel company), MediaTek, and Denso, Japanâs leading tier one. MIPSâs DNA  Kevin Krewell, principal analyst at Tirias Research, noted that Wave Computing and MIPS â both partly underwritten by Dado Banatao, managing partner of Tallwood Venture Capital â have âa natural affinity.â  Derek Meyer
